posts.name: Paige / Ruby || FRC 10063 & FTC 16008 Mentor üëë
posts.cooked:
Hello! I hope everyone is having a good day. I‚Äôm researching about branding and documentation right now, and could use some help on figuring out cohesion with these two topics. Currently I‚Äôm struggling to find an example of documentation that seamlessly integrates the brand, while not taking up too much room / sacrificing their content‚Äôs quality. This would be for technical binders and business plans.

Here‚Äôs some additional information that might be useful

We‚Äôre looking to use an online and collaborative software; such as Figma.

Mascots?

Minimal design pages that don‚Äôt add content value

Examples of documents include technical binders, business plans, financials, promotional materials, and flyers.

Thanks! EDIT: I also want to emphasize that I‚Äôm personally well versed in branding guidelines, and content writing for business documents. This post is mostly to look at what everyone else is doing and how we can put our own spin on it. Sorry if this was not clear.

posts.name: Dominick Ferone
posts.cooked:
RubyRoboKing:

We‚Äôre looking to use an online and collaborative software; such as Figma.

This wouldn‚Äôt be the use case of firms. You would be wanting Canva, or Adobe products. (Indesign for flyers/print, illustrator/photoshop for graphics/logos, premiere for videos.)

As for branding guidelines, if you check out FIRST ‚Äôs branding guideline you can see an example for setting up branding guidelines. You can get away with a  little less in-depth, but include cmyk/rgb/hex breakdown of team colors for consistency, and fonts to set up a standard.

Can help when hanging down to one another/designing  new content.

You can choose a few ways to always incorporate the brand. Make a button bumper with the logo on it or have a watermark.  (A common practice is having an area you constantly put the logo, and possibly adjust content to leave a safe space everytime.)

link_counts.title: FIRST Brand and Logo Files | FIRST

posts.name: Paige / Ruby || FRC 10063 & FTC 16008 Mentor üëë
posts.cooked:
I‚Äôve consistently used Canva since 2018-2019, and the software is not up to my liking as of recently. It doesn‚Äôt actually center/position elements correctly, major documents can overclock space especially on Chrome, and more (to be fair, this could be just my computer, but several others I‚Äôve used overclock easily and I don‚Äôt want to rely on having ‚Äúgood computers‚Äù to run it.) Not to mention it‚Äôs hard to discern from the free and paid content. With my previous FRC teams, we‚Äôve applied for their nonprofit license and have been denied for 3+ years, so I want to also become familiar with other software. Furthermore, I‚Äôm not sure if we have access to Adobe for the season, so I want to prioritize accessibility and collaboration, and expand from there. If we do, then that‚Äôs a priority. EDIT: For those who say don‚Äôt use Google Chrome, some school systems don‚Äôt allow other software to be used. This is to make sure that students can access it.

I‚Äôm mostly looking for how documents look over the content right now. I‚Äôve worked on several branding guidelines and business plans to help guide content along, it‚Äôs just how it looks. I‚Äôve seen many documents that may not be useful or easy to read cause they focus more on the brand. Just looking for some cohesion and simplicity.

posts.name: Jill
posts.cooked:
Here are our copies of some of our supporting documentation. We‚Äôve won both Imagery and several technical awards in the past two years, so I‚Äôd like to think we‚Äôre doing something right.

We use Canva and it absolutely has its annoying quirks, but the simplicity for making visually appealing content without tons of effort is a plus, alongside with collaborative features.

Canva pro features are available for free with an educator account, which can then be shared with ‚Äústudents‚Äù, which we have our team account as.

Technical Binder - I think is our best blend of content/visual Business Plan

posts.name: Paige / Ruby || FRC 10063 & FTC 16008 Mentor üëë
posts.cooked: Thank you! Canva hasn‚Äôt been up to my liking recently (as described above). It‚Äôs a great software for collaboration. If they fix it / make it more accessible, I‚Äôd be using it no problem. My previous teams didn‚Äôt have access to the educator accounts because they didn‚Äôt belong to a school, and that seemed to be the hang-up on it. I‚Äôll take a look and see if it‚Äôll be different with this team.

posts.cooked:
Our documentation can be pretty well summed up from our Safety Manual and Buisiness Plan here: https://www.fpsrobotics.com/resources.htm

We provide graphics every once in a while when neccesary to prove a point or explain a statistic, but otherwise the main graphics is just the title page we get Graphics to make each year. Besides that its just font, coloring, spacing and other things which we try and hold standard between all of the documents.

posts.name: Dominick Ferone
posts.cooked: You can try Adobe express, as it‚Äôs the free option that is similar to canva. Or for a free photoshop alternative there is photopea.

posts.name: Itay Kaufman
posts.cooked:
RubyRoboKing:

We‚Äôre looking to use an online and collaborative software; such as Figma.

I feel like media, branding, and graphic design is a less developed side of FRC , so there are two ways to approach it:

Use basic websites that anyone could learn how to use easily (Canva, Slides, etc)

Use common softwares in the industry (Adobe‚Äôs Creative Cloud, Figma, Affinity)

In my team, I prefer the second option - just like the software team won‚Äôt use Scratch (or LabView) and mechanics wont use TinkerCAD, I believe that the media team should be no exception and use the products that are being used in the industry.

Adobe has great collaborative features - not as great as figma, but still usually enough.

If you believe that jumping into Adobe is tough, I‚Äôd recommend trying Affinity / Figma. Affinity is an Adobe clone but much cheaper. I am not sure about its integration and collaborative features but worth checking out. Figma is another great option being used mainly for UI UX but can also serve as a great platform for FRC . Their collaborative features are just like Google Docs, which I believe is what you‚Äôre looking for.

tldr: Figma

posts.name: cy [alum]
posts.cooked:
Figma‚Äôs use case is mostly web/UI/screen design. Fine if you‚Äôre designing a team‚Äôs website from scratch or using their whiteboard like features to brainstorm, but I wouldn‚Äôt use it for print.

I‚Äôm glad you brought up Affinity, though, the cost is much more reasonable than Adobe (though a school hosting a team may already be footing the bill for that).

posts.name: Itay Kaufman
posts.cooked: I have seen people use it for designing posts and more, it is really usable for designing digitaly. If talking about printing, yeah I guess it is less common for that (didn‚Äôt think about that aspect when writing the comment).
